WindowComponent Class Reference

#include <WindowComponent.h>

Inheritance diagram for WindowComponent:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

A window component is a component that is a direct or indirect child of a window.

It provides access to the window by offering a getWindow method.

See also:
getWindow()

Definition at line 21 of file WindowComponent.h.

Member Function Documentation

void appendListener (  Listener *  listener  )  [inherited]
 

Adds a component listener at the end of the listeners of this component.

Appended listeners are called last.

Parameters:
listener The listener to be added.
Warning:
Listeners are auto-deleting when they are not listening to any component anymore. So you should not hold any references to them and you should not manually delete them.

void appendWidget (  Widget *  widget  )  [inherited]
 

Adds a component widget at the end of the widgets of this component.

Appended widgets are considered last.

Parameters:
widget The widget to be added.
Note:
Widgets may only be added to one component at a time.

After the call, the memory is owned by this object. You should not delete it, it will be done automatically.

void cancelEffects (   )  [inherited]
 

Cancels all effects currently running for this component.

This method is useful before added new effects.

void center (   )  [inherited]
 

Moves the component to be located in the center of its parent.

virtual void destroy (   )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Removes the component from the Glaziery system to destroy it.

First performs operations before the component is destroyed, then adds it to the Desktop's list of disposables.

Note:
The component is added to the list of disposable components. Nevertheless, the memory is still available until the next call to Desktop::draw() (the next frame).

This is an ungraceful removal, without user interaction and close notifications, but with destroy noficiation. E.g. for windows, use Window::close() to close normally.

Reimplemented in Popup, and Window.

void destroyChild (  Component *  child  )  [protected, inherited]
 

Destroys a component, if it is a child of this component.

If not (which is illegal), an exception is thrown.

Parameters:
child The child to be destroyed.

virtual void draw (  DrawingContext &  context  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Draws the component to the display surface.

This is usually achieved by delegating to the current skin.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
Note:
The caller is responsible for not calling this method if the component is invisible.
See also:

virtual EventTarget* getEventTargetAt (  Vector  position  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns the event target at a given position that is setup to receive pointer events.

For popup components, this is always true, for windows, this is true if and only if the pointer event mode is active or inactive, but bypassing windows are treated as not existing (transparent for events), and for widgets, this depends on the widget's hit test (isHitAt()).

This is a deep search: The desktop delegates to the found window or popup component, which delegates to the client area and so on.

Parameters:
position The position relative to the event target's origin. For components, this is their absolute position, for widgets, this is the absolute position of their component.
Returns:
The event receiving event target at the position or NULL, if there is no target.

Reimplemented in FieldsArea, SingleFieldArea, SplittingArea, TabbingArea, ListField, ScrollingField, SingleFieldPopup, and Window.

virtual Component* getFocusChild (   )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns the child component that has focus within this parent.

Returns:
The child component that has focus within this parent or NULL, if this component has no children or if focussing is not subject of this component.

Reimplemented in FieldsArea, SingleFieldArea, SplittingArea, TabbingArea, ListField, SingleFieldPopup, and Window.

void* getModel (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Returns:
The application (or game) defined data.

Returns whether this component has focus within its parent, and all ancestor's have focus within their respective parent.

Only one component in the entire desktop has focus at any time (except that the parent of a focus component also has focus, of course).

Returns:

bool isDisposed (   )  [inherited]
 

Returnw whether the component has being destroyed by the destroy() method.

Returns:

virtual bool isDynamic (   )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns whether the display content (in terms of the draw() method) is dynamic.

In this case, the content has to be drawn every frame, so e.g. the window cannot cache it. Default is false. Overriding this method to return true is an alternative to calling invalidate manually every frame.

Returns:
whether the display content is dynamic.
See also:
draw()

Vector  position
)  [protected, inherited]
 

Moves a related component (child, parent, ...) within its parent.

No veto is possible, and the parent is not notified.

Note:

moveInternal()

moveTo()

virtual bool moveInternal (  Vector  position,
bool  vetoable,
bool  notifyParent
)  [protected, virtual]
 

Moves the component within its parent, handling listeners and vetoing.

This method is called internally by the move overload, and by parents moveing a child.

Parameters:
position The new position relative to its parent.
vetoable Whether the movement can be vetoed.
notifyParent Whether the method has been called from the parent (e.g. onChildMoved() or onChildResized()). In this case, the child event handlers are not called again, to prevent an endless recursion or other inappropriate behavior.
Returns:
Whether the move was performed. Any veto results in false.
See also:
moveTo()

onChildResized()

bool moveRelative (  Vector  delta  )  [inherited]
 

Moves the component relatively.

This calls the listeners' onMoving() method first. If any veto occurs, the operation is aborted. Otherwise, the component is moved and the listeners' onMoved() method is called.

Parameters:
delta The translation relative to the current position.
Returns:
Whether the move was performed. Any veto results in false.

Moves the component absolutely within its parent.

This calls the listeners' onMoving() method first. If any veto occurs, the operation is aborted. Otherwise, the component is moved and the listeners' onMoved() method is called.

Parameters:
position The new position relative to its parent.
Returns:
Whether the move was performed. Any veto results in false.

On Windows systems, this is SHIFT+TAB. Back tabs step the focus from field to field in backward order.

Vector  oldPosition
)  [virtual, inherited]

E.g. move the parent, too, if the child uses all the area of the parent, or ignore the event if the child can move freely.

bool  rangeSelection,
bool  keepSelection
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Handles the event that the event target is clicked (usually using the left mouse button).

A click is raised after the mouse has been pressed and released, and no dragging operation has started.

position The position where the click occurred relative to the upper-left corner of the component.
rangeSelection Whether to keep the current selection start, e.g. on Windows systems, because the SHIFT button was pressed.
keepSelection Whether to keep the existing selection, e.g. on Windows systems, because the CTRL button was pressed.

virtual void onDragEnd (  Vector  position,
EventTarget *  dropTarget
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Handles the event that a dragging operation ended (successful or not).

This is when a dragging operation is in progress and the primary pointer button has been released. This method is called on the dragged object (compare to onDropped()).

Parameters:
position The absolute position were the button was released.
dropTarget The event target this object is dropped on. May be NULL, indicating that the dragging operation failed: There is no target at the drop position or it does not support dropping.
See also:

virtual long onHold (  Vector  position,
long  holdTime
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Handles the event that, after the event target is pressed down (usually using the left mouse button), the pointer is not moved, but the button has not yet been released.

onHold() is called in the time between onPress() and onRelease(). Glaziery provides the time between the last call of onHold() and this one. It expects that the onHold implementation issues in its return value the hold time not consumed. If 0 is returned, all the time has been consumed and the holdTime reflects only the time between two consecutive onHold() calls each time. If a positive value is returned, this value is added to the next holdTime value. This helps to implement operations that have to be performed after some time has elapsed, while not losing remaining milli seconds. The following code snippet illustrates this operation: 


 long MyClass::onHold(Vector position, long holdTime)
 {
 	while (holdTime >= 100)
 	{
 		performSomeOperation();
 		holdTime -= 100;
 	}
 	return holdTime;
 }
Parameters:
position The current position of the pointer relative to the upper-left corner of the event target's origin. For components, this is their absolute position, for widgets, this is the absolute position of their component.
holdTime The hold time between the last call of onHold() and this one, plus the hold time not consumed in the last call of onHold(). The time's unit is milli seconds.
Returns:
The hold time this method has not consumed in milli seconds.
See also:
onPress()

onRelease()

virtual void onHotKey (  char  character  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Handles the event that a hot key has been pressed on the event target.

Hot keys represent special characters e.g. to easily access fields (indicated by underlined characters).

Parameters:
character The hot key characters pressed.

Reimplemented in FieldsArea, and TabbingArea.

virtual void onKeyStroke (  Key *  key  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Handles the event that a planned key stroke has been pressed on the event target.

Key strokes are usually received by key stroke fields. When the desktop is in key stroke mode, the next key pressed should be sent to this method. This is useful e.g. to define keyboard layouts for games.

Parameters:
key The key stroke key. The memory is provided by the client. It may be destroyed by the client after the call, so the listeners etc. should not keep a reference to it. Instead, they may call the key's clone method.
See also:
Desktop::isKeyStrokeMode()

Key::clone()

Reimplemented in KeyStrokeField.

virtual void onLostFocus (   )  [virtual, inherited]
 

First notifies the listeners of the deepest grand-child of a focus loss, then its parent, and so on, until this component is reached, which is then notified (calling the listeners' onLostFocus() method).

See also:
Listener::onLostFocus()

Reimplemented in Popup.

virtual void onMoveDown (  bool  rangeSelection,
bool  keepSelection
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Handles the event that the DOWN key is pressed on the event target.

Parameters:
rangeSelection Whether to keep the current selection start, e.g. on Windows systems, because the SHIFT button was pressed.
keepSelection Whether to keep the existing selection, e.g. on Windows systems, because the CTRL button was pressed.

Reimplemented in ListField::RowsField, Selector, and TextField.

virtual void onTab (  bool  secondary  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Handles the event that the TAB key is pressed on the event target.

Tabs step the focus from field to field.

Parameters:
secondary Whether the secondary tabbing is used. E.g., on Windows systems, this is done by holding the control key.

Reimplemented in FieldsArea, SplittingArea, and TabbingArea.

void prependListener (  Listener *  listener  )  [inherited]
 

Adds a component listener at the beginning of the listeners of this component.

Prepended listeners are called first.

Parameters:
listener The listener to be added.
Warning:
Listeners are auto-deleting when they are not listening to any component anymore. So you should not hold any references to them and you should not manually delete them.

void prependWidget (  Widget *  widget  )  [inherited]
 

Adds a component widget at the beginning of the widgets of this component.

Prepended widgets are considered first.

Parameters:
widget The widget to be added.
Note:
Widgets may only be added to one component at a time.

After the call, the memory is owned by this object. You should not delete it, it will be done automatically.

void removeListener (  Listener *  listener  )  [inherited]
 

Removes a listener from the list of component listeners and then deletes it.

Parameters:
listener The listener to be removed and deleted.
Warning:
Listeners are auto-deleting when they are not listening to any component anymore. So you should not hold any references to them.

void removeWidget (  Widget *  widget  )  [inherited]
 

Removes a widget from the list of component widgets and then deletes it.

Parameters:
widget The widget to be removed and deleted.

virtual bool resize (  Vector  size  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Resizes the component.

This calls the listeners' onResizing() method first. If any veto occurs, the operation is aborted. Otherwise, the component is resized and the listeners' onResized() method is called.

Parameters:
size The new size.
Returns:
Whether the resize was performed. Any veto results in false.

Reimplemented in Field, and Window.

void resizeComponentWithoutVeto (  Component *  relatedComponent,
Vector  size
)  [protected, inherited]
 

Resizes a related component (child, parent, ...).

No veto is possible, and the parent is not notified.

Parameters:
relatedComponent The related component to be resized.
size The new size.
Note:
Use this method only from within components that have to move related components. This method delegates to the moveInternal() method.
See also:
resize()

resizeInternal()

virtual bool resizeInternal (  Vector  size,
bool  vetoable,
bool  notifyParent
)  [protected, virtual]
 

Resizes the component, handling listeners and vetoing.

This method is called internally by the resize overload, and by parents resizing a child.

Parameters:
size The new size.
vetoable Whether the resizing can be vetoed.
notifyParent Whether the method has been called from the parent (e.g. onChildMoved() or onChildResized()). In this case, the child event handlers are not called again, to prevent an endless recursion or other inappropriate behavior.
Returns:
Whether the resize was performed. Any veto results in false.
See also:
resize()

onChildMoved()

onChildResized()

Reimplemented from Component.

Reimplemented in SingleFieldArea, SplittingArea, TabbingArea, ListField, and ScrollingField.

void setComponentParent (  Component *  child  )  [protected, inherited]
 

Sets the parent of a related child component when adding the child to this component.

You cannot change a parent once it has been set, except if you unset the parent first, which is not recommended for regular cases.

Parameters:
child The child to set the parent to this component.
Note:
Do not use this method in application (or game) code. Use this method in the parent component when implementing a method that adds a child (e.g. appendField in FieldsArea).
See also:
unsetComponentParent()

getParent()

void setModel (  void *  model  )  [inherited]
 

Sets the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Parameters:
model The application (or game) defined data.

void setVisible (  bool  visible  )  [inherited]
 

Shows or hides the component (makes it visible or invisible).

Note:
This is a convenience method, it delegates to show() or hide().
See also:
show()

hide()

virtual void show (   )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Shows the component (makes it visible again).

Reimplemented in ClientArea, and Field.

virtual bool supportsDraggingAt (  Vector  position  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns whether the event target supports to be dragged at a given position.

By default, it does not at any position.

Parameters:
position The position to start the dragging, relative to the pointer target's origin (in terms of getOrigin()).
Returns:
Whether the event target supports to be dragged at the position.
See also:
getOrigin()

virtual bool supportsDroppingAt (  Vector  position,
EventTarget *  draggedEventTarget
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns whether the event target supports to be the drop target for another object that is currently dragged.

By default, not dropping is supported at any position.

Parameters:
position The position to drop the dragged component on, relative to the event target's origin (in terms of getOrigin()).
draggedEventTarget The event target that is currently dragged. Use dynamic casting or other techniques to determine the type of this object.
Returns:
Whether the event target supports dropping of the dragged object at the position.
See also:
getOrigin()

void unsetComponentParent (  Component *  child  )  [protected, inherited]
 

Unsets the parent of a related child component in the rare cases of removing the child from this component again.

Parameters:
child The child to unset the parent of.
Note:
Do not use this method in application (or game) code. Use this method in the parent component when implementing a method that removes a child (e.g. PopupWindow).
See also:
setComponentParent()

getParent()
